novel_text:
The air over the Quay, even an hour before sunrise, tasted of salt and diesel fumes. A fine, gritty meal for a creature the size of a man’s thumb. Kaelan ignored it. He had learned long ago to filter the crass tang of the big folk’s world from the purer elements he worked with. Today, his material was the nascent light of dawn itself, a single, fraying strand of pearlescent gold that had snagged on the mast of a fishing trawler named ‘The Salty Dog’. If left untended, it would snap before the sun had properly breached the horizon, causing a momentary, imperceptible flicker in the morning’s arrival. Mortals wouldn’t notice. A few gulls might cry out in momentary confusion. But Kaelan would know. The world would be just that little bit less perfect, a single stitch dropped in the grand tapestry. And Kaelan did not abide dropped stitches.

He clung to a rust-pitted stanchion, his gossamer wings, patterned like a pebble from the shore, pressed tight to his back to avoid a snag. The wind was a bully this high up, a buffeting force that threatened to peel him from his perch and send him spiralling into the greasy, rainbow-sheened water below. It was delicate work. The sort of work that demanded absolute stillness, a quiet mind, and fingers that could coax a thread of mist without turning it to vapour. He held his breath. Slowly, Kaelan reached out, his tiny, three-fingered hands glowing with a soft internal luminescence. He wasn't grabbing the light. You couldn't grab light. You had to persuade it. He began to weave, not with a shuttle and loom, but with focused intent, his fingers dancing in the air, knotting the intangible. He was a Weaver, one of the last in the Poole Harbour clutch. His skill was not in making, but in mending. He could re-stitch a spider's web, bind the scent of gorse back into a bruised flower, or, on a very good day, persuade a fractured moonbeam to heal itself.

The golden thread responded to his touch, the frayed ends twisting, braiding, flowing back into a single, cohesive strand. He worked a Weaver’s Knot—a complex, seven-loop binding that was both stronger than the original thread and utterly invisible. A sigh of pure satisfaction escaped his lips, a tiny puff of air that was immediately snatched away by the wind. The strand of dawn was secure. The sun could now rise without blemish. His work here was done. He allowed himself a small, tight smile. It was a good mend. Clean. Precise. He was about to scuttle back down the stanchion, towards the relative safety of the pilings and crevices of the Quay, when he felt it.

It was a wrongness. A sour note in the symphony of the waking harbour. Not the familiar discord of humanity—the groan of engines, the distant shout of a deckhand—but something deeper. Something that felt like a plucked string inside his own chest. He cocked his head, his large, dark eyes scanning the panorama. The vast, dark water of the harbour stretched out towards Brownsea Island, a smudge of deeper black against the charcoal sky. The chain ferry was a slumbering metal beast on the Sandbanks side. Everything looked as it should. Yet, the feeling persisted. It was a subtle unraveling. He scrambled down the cold metal, his bare feet finding purchase on rivet heads and flakes of rust, until he reached the damp, creosote-soaked timbers of the pier. Here, in the under-world of the Quay, the sounds and smells were sharper, more immediate. The slap of water against wood, the scuttling of unseen crabs, the pervasive stink of brine and decay.

An elder sprite, Elara, was waiting for him, perched on a discarded oyster shell. Her wings, the colour of dried seaweed, were tattered at the edges, and her face was a roadmap of worry. She’d been a Weaver once, but her hands were now gnarled with age and the damp, better suited to prophesying aches in her joints than mending the world.
“You felt it too,” she stated. It wasn’t a question. Her voice was the rasp of beetle-chitin on dry leaves.

Kaelan nodded, hopping from a damp patch to a relatively dry spot of wood. “A discord. Over by the trawlers. I thought at first it was just a snapped dawn-thread, but the mend felt… slick.” He struggled for the right word. “Like I was stitching oil to water. It held, but it didn't *want* to.”

Elara’s dark eyes seemed to shrink, becoming hard little beads of jet. “It’s him. It’s his humour spreading again. Like a stain.”

Kaelan’s stomach tightened. He didn't need to ask who ‘he’ was. There was only one sprite in living memory who could cause such a feeling, a sprite whose very existence was an act of metaphysical vandalism. Bartholomew. Barth, to all who feared or loathed him, which was everyone.

“What did he do?” Kaelan asked, his voice low.

“You know what he does,” Elara rasped, shifting on her shell. “He tells jokes. He was seen over by the reed beds of the Hole’s Bay mudflats last night. Old Corvus the woodlouse said he heard him. A chuckle first, like stones rolling in a tin can. Then the words.” She shuddered, a tremor that shook her whole tiny frame. “He told a joke to a patch of sea-thrift. Asked it what the difference was between a flower and a puddle of sick.”

Kaelan felt a wave of nausea. “And?”

“And now there’s a patch of land by the water’s edge, about a stride across for a big folk, where nothing grows. It’s not just dead, Kaelan. It’s… resolved. The very soil has forgotten how to be soil. It’s just brown grit. The thrift didn’t just die, it… it believed the punchline.”

This was Barth’s particular brand of horror. His jokes weren’t just words. They were corrosive suggestions whispered to the fabric of reality. He didn’t use magic in the way Kaelan or the other sprites did. He didn’t weave or bind or persuade. He found a loose thread in the world’s logic and he pulled, not with force, but with a perfectly constructed, terribly inappropriate jest. He could tell a stone it was actually a bubble, and it would float away for a second before popping into dust. He could ask a cloud why it was in such a hurry and it would stop, forgetting its purpose, and simply hang in the sky until it curdled and fell as greasy, black rain. His humour was the auditory equivalent of rust, of rot, of entropy.

“He can’t be allowed to continue,” Kaelan said, the words feeling heavy and useless in his mouth. “The clutch-elders…”

“The elders are old,” Elara cut in, her voice sharp with a frustration that mirrored his own. “They hide. They wring their hands and talk of the old ways and how things are not as they once were. They hope he’ll get bored and wander off. But he’s not getting bored, Kaelan. He’s getting better. His jokes are becoming more… ambitious.”

As if to punctuate her words, a sudden, unnatural silence fell over their small section of the under-quay. The constant, rhythmic lapping of the water against the pilings ceased. Not faded, not quieted. It simply stopped. Kaelan and Elara froze, listening to the non-sound. It was more disturbing than any noise. The water was still there, he could see its dark, undulating surface. But it was making no noise. It had forgotten how.

Then they heard it. A faint, wheezing chuckle drifting from further down the pier. It was a wet, unpleasant sound, full of phlegm and malice.

“Why is the sea so quiet?” a voice whispered, seeming to come from all directions at once. It was a thin, reedy voice, but it carried a weight that made the timbers vibrate. Kaelan felt the hairs on his arms stand on end.

The voice paused, a perfect, theatrical beat.

“Because it saw the Quay and didn’t want to wake the sleepers!”

The punchline landed in the air like a dead weight. And then, a sound returned to the water. But it wasn’t the familiar, gentle lapping. It was a thick, syrupy slopping. A glutinous, sucking noise, like mud trying to swallow a boot. Kaelan peered over the edge of the beam. The water below had changed. It had thickened, its surface now disturbingly viscous, covered in a film like cooling gravy. A dead fish floated by, not on the water, but half-submerged in it, trapped in the gelid surface. The very nature of the water had been perverted by a single, stupid joke.

“No,” Kaelan breathed. He could feel the wrongness spreading, a stain of corrupted physics. This wasn’t a fray to be mended. This was a fundamental truth that had been lied to, and had believed the lie. He looked at Elara. The worry in her eyes had been replaced by stark terror.

“He’s close,” she whispered. “He’s never been this close to the heart of the clutch.”

Kaelan felt a surge of something cold and hard in his chest. It wasn't fear, not entirely. It was a cold, sharp anger. An artisan’s fury at the sight of a masterpiece being defaced. His world, with all its intricate, fragile beauty, was being turned into a grotesque caricature by a nihilistic jester. He looked down at his hands, the faint light still glowing around his fingertips. His skills were for mending, for healing, for reinforcing the fragile order of things. But what good was a needle against a flood? What good was a Weaver when the very threads were being taught to unravel themselves from within? He didn’t have an answer. But as the foul, slopping sound of the bewitched water echoed beneath him, he knew he had to find one. He had to stop Barth. Not because the elders decreed it, not for the glory of the clutch, but because the alternative was a world where the sea made the sound of mud and flowers turned to sick at the telling of a bad joke. And that was no world at all.Kaelan moved towards the sound, a grim determination setting his tiny jaw. The slopping of the corrupted water was an offense to every one of his senses. He had to see. He had to understand the extent of the damage. Elara scrabbled after him, her tattered wings dragging on the damp wood. “Don’t go near him, Kaelan! There’s nothing you can do. You mend things that are broken, but this… this isn’t broken. It’s been… convinced. It’s worse.” Her voice was a high, desperate whine, lost under the thick, unsettling sound of the water. Kaelan didn’t reply. He couldn’t. The artisan in him was screaming louder than Elara’s fear. This was not a dropped stitch; this was someone taking a blowtorch to the tapestry.

He reached the edge of the pier and peered down the long, dark corridor of the under-quay. The air was thick with a new smell, mingling with the salt and creosote—an acrid, chemical odour like burnt sugar. Further down, silhouetted against a gap in the pilings that showed the faintly lightening sky, was a figure. It was another sprite, hunched over, his form distorted and twitching with silent laughter. Even from this distance, Kaelan could see the wrongness of him. His wings were not like a pebble or a leaf or a moth, but were a chaotic, mismatched pair. One looked like a shard of oily, rainbow-slicked glass, the other was a tattered piece of a lottery ticket, its numbers faded and meaningless. This had to be Barth.

Barth was talking to something, his reedy voice a low murmur that Kaelan couldn’t quite decipher. His audience was a cluster of barnacles, clinging to a great wooden piling. As Kaelan watched, his stomach churning, Barth leaned in close, as if sharing a secret, and delivered a final, whispered line. A moment of absolute stillness followed. Then, one by one, the barnacles began to squeak. It was a high, thin sound, like air escaping a pinpricked balloon. They detached from the wood, not falling, but drifting lazily upwards, spinning in the air like grey, calcified seeds. They floated up through the gaps in the pier decking and were gone, having been convinced they were bubbles. Barth let out another wet, wheezing chuckle of delight. He had taught a colony of sessile crustaceans a joke about gravity.

This was the antithesis of everything Kaelan was. A Weaver worked with the world as it was, honouring its rules, respecting its integrity. Barth saw the rules as a cosmic joke waiting for a punchline. He saw the integrity of a thing as a set-up, a straight man for his nihilistic wit. Anger, cold and pure, burned away the last of Kaelan’s fear. He wasn’t a warrior. He didn’t have a thorn-blade or a pincer-claw like the clutch’s foragers and guards. He had his hands, his intent, and a profound, unshakable belief in the way things were *meant* to be. Perhaps that was a weapon of its own. He dropped from the beam, landing silently on the cross-strut below, and began to move towards the jester, a tiny, determined point of light in the deepening corruption of the under-quay.

Elara watched him go, a tiny sound of despair caught in her throat. She pressed herself into the shadows, making herself small, a creature of the old ways hiding from a horror the old ways had never prepared them for. Kaelan, however, felt a strange sense of clarity as he moved. The world around him was subtly warped. A patch of sea-lettuce had curled in on itself, trying to remember the colour green. A length of discarded fishing line was attempting to tie itself into a hangman’s noose, having been told a bleak joke about futility. Each wrongness was a breadcrumb, a testament to Barth's passing, and each one fuelled Kaelan’s resolve. He was no longer just a mender. He was an antibody, drawn to a sickness that threatened the entire organism. He crept closer, his internal light dimmed to a faint ember, his feet making no sound on the slime-coated beams. He was ten feet away when Barth spoke again, his voice oozing with mock conviviality.

“Well, well, well,” Barth chirped, without turning around. “If it isn’t the Golden Boy of the Weavers. The little stitch-witch himself. Come to admire my work? Or perhaps you’ve got a needle and thread big enough to sew the sea back together?” He finally turned, and Kaelan got his first proper look at him. Barth was thin and wiry, his skin the colour of a day-old bruise. His eyes were mismatched too; one was a bright, feverish blue, the other a dull, bored brown. They darted and danced, never settling, alight with a manic, destructive glee. A twisted smile stretched his mouth, a rictus of mirth that held no warmth at all. “It’s a bit of a fixer-upper, I’ll grant you,” he gestured with a flourish at the glutinous water. “But I think it has a certain… honesty. Don’t you? The sea always secretly wanted to be sludge. I just gave it permission.”

Kaelan stood his ground on the beam, the foul smell of Barth’s work thick in his throat. He kept his own voice level, fighting to keep it from trembling. “This isn’t permission, Barth. It’s a violation. You’re poisoning the order of things for your own amusement.”

Barth threw his head back and laughed, that same wet, grating sound. “Order! Oh, you precious little fool. There is no order. It’s all just a poorly told story, and the storyteller is a drunk. I’m just pointing out the plot holes. What do you call a spider’s web that catches the dew?” he asked, his mad eyes fixing on Kaelan. Before Kaelan could even process the question, Barth snapped the punchline. “A net loss!” As he spoke, a nearby web, a perfect orb beaded with pristine droplets, sagged. The dewdrops, suddenly imbued with impossible weight, tore through the silk strands, and the whole delicate structure collapsed into a useless, sticky tangle. The spider, a garden-orb weaver Kaelan had seen every morning for a month, scurried into a crack, its world literally torn apart.

Kaelan flinched as if struck. The casual, instantaneous destruction was obscene. He raised his hands, the soft light in them flaring instinctively. He couldn’t fix the sea, not all at once, but maybe… maybe he could fight one lie with one truth. He focused on the ruined web, on the memory of its perfection, on the fundamental law of surface tension and the inherent strength of spider-silk. He began to weave, not touching the web, but persuading its memory. He was trying to remind it of its own nature, to stitch its truth back into place over the hole Barth’s joke had made. “The web is strong,” he whispered, his fingers tracing patterns in the air. “The dew is light. This is their nature.”

The tangled strands quivered. A few of them tightened, trying to reform their old connections. It was like trying to mend a cloth that was actively fighting back, a fabric that now believed its purpose was to be torn. Barth watched him, his smile widening with sadistic curiosity. “Oh, that’s adorable. You’re trying to tell it a better story? So earnest. So… dull.” He leaned forward, his reedy voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper aimed at the struggling web. “But why bother holding on? Letting go is so much easier. What did the thread say to the spider? ‘I’m hanging on by you!’”

The effect was immediate. The faint flicker of order Kaelan had coaxed into the web died instantly. The strands went limp, not just broken but… resigned. The web gave up. It accepted its new state of uselessness. Kaelan felt the resistance in his weaving vanish, replaced by a dead, unresponsive void. A trickle of sweat ran down his temple. He had tried to out-weave a punchline, and had failed. It was like trying to patch a hole with water. Barth’s power didn't just break things; it convinced them that being broken was their true, and funnier, state.The echo of his failure was a cold, dead space in the air. Kaelan felt it as a physical vacancy, a pocket of nothing where the intricate logic of the web had been. He lowered his hands, the light within them flickering uncertainly. It was one thing to mend a tear caused by a clumsy gull or a brute gust of wind; those were wounds inflicted from the outside. This was a sickness from within, a rot of the soul. The web hadn't just broken; it had surrendered its very identity.

Barth clapped his mismatched hands together, a slow, mocking applause that sounded like stones cracking. “Bravo, bravo! A valiant effort. You see, this is your problem, Weaver. You think the world is a beautiful, intricate thing that sometimes gets a little torn. But you’re wrong. The world is a cosmic pratfall, a long, drawn-out joke at its own expense. I’m not breaking it. I’m just delivering the punchlines it’s been waiting to hear.” He gestured around at the corrupted space beneath the pier. “You’re a janitor, sweeping up. I’m a philosopher, revealing the truth. And the truth,” he leaned in, his reedy voice dropping to a hiss, “is that it’s all meaningless. And that’s hilarious.”

Every word was a splinter under Kaelan’s skin. Meaningless? He thought of the perfect, seven-loop knot he had just tied in the strand of dawnlight. He thought of the intricate patterns on his own wings, the result of a million tiny choices made by chance and time. He thought of the complex symphony of the harbour—the tides, the cycles of rust and renewal, the dance of predator and prey. It wasn't meaningless. It was the most meaningful thing he knew. It was everything. And this… creature… was turning it all into a sneering, nihilistic gag. A different kind of fire lit in Kaelan’s chest, colder and harder than his earlier anger. It was the icy resolve of a craftsman whose life’s work has been declared a joke.

He looked at his hands again. They were made for mending, for persuading. But persuasion relied on a shared understanding, a common belief in the thing being mended. He could not persuade the sea that it was water, because Barth had already convinced it that it was sludge. He couldn’t persuade the web to be strong, because Barth had already proven that letting go was funnier. The logic was undeniable. He could not win by arguing with a punchline. He could not mend what no longer believed in being whole. The realisation was terrifying, but it was also freeing. If mending was impossible, then he had to do something else. He was a Weaver. And a weave wasn’t just for repair. A good weave, a tight weave, was also for reinforcement.

Barth seemed to sense the shift in Kaelan, the change from bewildered fury to a grim, focused stillness. The jester’s smile faltered for a fraction of a second, his darting eyes pausing on Kaelan’s luminous hands. He had expected despair, a retreat. This quiet defiance was new, and therefore irritating. “Well, this has been fun,” he said with a dismissive flick of his lottery-ticket wing. “But I’m tired of heckling the background characters. I think it’s time to talk to the star of the show.” He turned and scurried away down the pier, his form a twitching silhouette against the lightening sky. “There’s a piling down here, the oldest one. They say the whole Quay is built around it. The Sovereign Piling. Solid, dependable, the heart of the clutch. I’ve been working on a real knee-slapper for it. Something about termites and ambition.”

Kaelan’s blood ran cold. The Sovereign Piling was more than just wood. It was their history, their anchor. It was the first place the Poole Harbour clutch had found shelter, its ancient, sea-soaked timber holding the memories of a thousand generations. To corrupt it would be to poison the very heart of their world. He didn’t hesitate. Pushing off the beam, he unfurled his wings and launched himself into the foul-smelling air, a tiny, glowing missile of desperate purpose. He flew low and fast, weaving through the forest of supporting struts, the thick, slopping sound of the gelid water a constant, nauseating drumbeat below. The world around him was a gallery of Barth’s petty cruelties. A line of rust on a metal plate was weeping, literally dripping flakes onto the wood below after being told a joke about its own decay. A small puddle shimmered and trembled, trying to achieve escape velocity after being convinced it was a rocket.

He had to get there first. He pushed himself faster, his pebble-patterned wings beating a frantic rhythm. He couldn't fix what Barth broke. He knew that now. He couldn't un-tell the joke. But what if he could make the piling deaf to it? What if he could reinforce its reality so strongly, bind its own truth to it so tightly, that Barth's corrosive wit would find no purchase? It wasn't mending. It was shielding. It was an act of magical conservation. Instead of stitching a tear, he would weave a knot of pure, unassailable *being* into the piling’s very core. He would remind it of its strength, its age, its purpose, its deep, quiet dignity. He would weave a truth so profound and fundamental that no joke, no matter how clever or cruel, could unravel it. It was a Weaver’s skill used not as a needle, but as a shield. He didn’t know if it would work. He didn’t even know if it was possible. But as he flew through the corrupted morning, with the sound of a mad sprite’s chuckling echoing behind him, he knew he had to try.Chapter 2

He flew like a glowing dart through the forest of pier legs. The world he passed was a fever dream of Barth’s making. A small colony of mussels, renowned for their stoicism, were chattering nervously to each other, convinced by a rumour that the tide was never coming back in. A stray piece of driftwood, told it was a snake, was trying to writhe its way across the sludge-water, its movements stiff and unconvincing. Kaelan forced himself not to look, not to feel the pang of each individual corruption. To do so would be to dilute his focus, to scatter his intent. All that mattered was the Sovereign Piling. He could feel its presence now, not as a wrongness, but as a deep, resonant rightness in the chaotic symphony. It was a bass note, a foundation, and Barth was marching towards it with a metaphysical sledgehammer.

He arrived moments before his rival. The Sovereign Piling was immense, a pillar of ancient oak that was thicker than three men standing shoulder-to-shoulder. Its surface was a testament to time, scarred with the ghosts of long-rusted-away iron bands, pitted by shipworms, and softened by a coat of algae and velvet-fine sea moss. It plunged deep into the harbour bed and soared up into the main structure of the Quay, a central column around which everything else had been built. It smelled of deep, cold brine, of wet earth from its long-forgotten life as a tree, and something more: a profound, unshakable scent of permanence. Generations of the clutch had been born in its crevices, had sheltered from winter gales in its lee, and had watched the sun rise over its steadfast form. It was not a piling; it was their home.

Without a second’s hesitation, Kaelan landed on a projecting knob of wood and pressed both his hands against the piling’s flank. The wood was cold and damp, but beneath the surface, he could feel it—a slow, deep, geologic thrum. The piling’s memory. He closed his eyes and let his own light flow from his fingertips, not over the surface, but *into* it. This was no surface mend. He was not stitching frayed edges. He was delving into the very heartwood of the thing, seeking the core of its identity. He found the threads of its being: the concentric rings of its growth, the memory of sunlight on its leaves, the stoic endurance of a thousand winter storms, the faint, layered echoes of a million tiny sprite hands that had clung to it for safety. His own hands began to move, his fingers dancing against the wood. He was weaving those threads of truth together. He was not telling the piling what it was; he was reminding it, with all the force of his own belief in order and purpose. "Root," he thought, weaving the memory of its grip in the earth. "Heartwood," he projected, binding the concept of its strong, dense core. "Endurance. Shelter. Foundation. Home." Each concept was a knot, a reinforcement in the fabric of its reality.

A familiar, grating chuckle echoed from behind him. "Oh, this is rich," Barth sneered, sauntering into view from around a neighbouring strut. He stopped a few feet away, his mismatched eyes taking in the scene with theatrical amusement. "Look at you. Hugging the furniture. Are you trying to teach it a new trick? Or just polish it with your own self-importance?" He gestured with a lazy flick of his glass-shard wing. "You can't make it any more of a piling than it already is, you little pedant."

Kaelan did not answer. He couldn’t. His entire being was focused on the weave. The piling was responding. He could feel its immense, slow consciousness stirring, acknowledging the truths he was reinforcing. The faint light from his hands brightened, the patterns of his weaving becoming visible as shimmering lines of force that sank into the ancient oak, bathing the base of the pillar in a soft, protective luminescence. The scent of permanence, of deep, unassailable reality, grew stronger, pushing back against the acrid smell of burnt sugar and decay that clung to Barth like a shroud. This was his shield, a defence made of pure, concentrated is-ness.

Barth’s mocking smile tightened. He had clearly expected Kaelan to argue, to flail uselessly. This silent, focused opposition was infuriating. The light from Kaelan's work seemed to genuinely annoy him, a pure note in his carefully orchestrated symphony of discord. He took a step closer, his reedy voice taking on the cadence of a performer about to deliver his masterpiece. "You're too late, stitch-witch," he hissed. "I've had this one planned for weeks. It's my magnum opus. The joke that will bring the house down. Literally." He cleared his throat, a wet, rattling sound, and addressed the Sovereign Piling directly, his voice dripping with false intimacy.

"Alright, you big, strong, silent type. You've stood here a long time, holding everything up. Never a complaint. Terribly noble. Terribly boring." Barth’s grin widened into a predatory slit. "Let me ask you a question." He paused, letting the silence stretch, a showman milking the moment. Kaelan felt a tremor of pure malice in the air, a vibration that threatened to shake his delicate weave apart. He pressed harder, pouring every ounce of his will, his belief, his love for the world's perfect, ordered logic into the piling. The light around its base flared into a brilliant, defiant shield.

Barth ignored it. His mad blue eye fixed on the heart of the ancient wood. "What," he asked, his voice suddenly sharp and clear, "did the ambitious termite say to the Sovereign Piling?"The words hung in the air, a perfectly constructed vector of conceptual poison. Kaelan felt the psychic impact of them hit his weave like a physical blow. The light from his hands wavered, the intricate patterns of truth he had woven into the piling flickering like a faulty glow-worm. The joke wasn't just words; it was a syllogism of decay, a perfectly logical, terribly corrosive suggestion aimed at the very heart of the piling’s purpose.

“‘It’s nothing personal,’ he wheezed, his voice bubbling with glee, ‘I’m just here to undermine your authority!’”

The punchline landed. And the Sovereign Piling, for the first time in its centuries of existence, shuddered. It was not the tremor of a physical strain, but a deep, internal groan of conceptual conflict. A fine, dry powder of ancient wood began to sift down from deep within its core, a substance that wasn't sawdust but pure, desiccated doubt. The piling had understood the joke. It had processed the logic: it was a sovereign, an authority. To undermine was the natural ambition of a lesser power. The joke was, in its own terrible way, perfectly reasonable. Kaelan felt the threads of his weave—the concepts of ‘Foundation’ and ‘Strength’—begin to slacken, losing their tautness as the piling began to question its own role.

Barth howled with laughter, a triumphant, rattling crow of a sound that echoed through the under-quay. "Do you feel it, stitch-witch? Do you feel the beautiful, simple logic of it? It's giving up! It understands the gag! It's so much easier to be rubble than to hold up a world, isn't it?" The sifting dust became thicker. The deep, resonant thrum of the piling's being grew discordant, a beautiful bass note now soured by a new, grating frequency of self-destruction. Kaelan’s shield of pure being was failing, because the being itself no longer fully believed in its own purpose.

Desperation clawed at him. He couldn’t reinforce a truth that was actively being unpicked from the inside. He was trying to shout "You are strong!" at a being that was now contemplating the philosophical elegance of being weak. It was a losing argument. His entire approach was wrong. Weaving logic against a paradox was like trying to dam a river with a net. And then, as the great pillar groaned again, a sound of immense, slow-motion sorrow, a new thought sparked in Kaelan’s mind. Barth's power came from twisting the logic of a thing, its function, its name. He had attacked the *Sovereign Piling*. But that wasn't all it was. That was just its title. What was its *truth*?

He changed his weave. The shift was instinctive, desperate, and utterly profound. He stopped weaving the cold, hard facts of the piling's existence—its strength, its age, its function. Instead, he reached for something deeper, something Barth’s cynical wit could never touch. He reached for its soul. His fingers, still pressed against the wood, moved in a new, frantic, yet graceful dance. He stopped weaving concepts and started weaving memories. He poured the collective memory of the clutch into the wood, a thousand years of lived experience. He wove the feeling of a young sprite’s hand finding a secure grip during a storm. He sat up, every muscle protesting, his bruised ribs sending a sharp, stabbing reminder of their descent. Beside him, Barth lay exactly as he had been left, a discarded doll in a bed of moss, his breathing so shallow it was almost imperceptible. He felt the echo of its making, the chisel in a mason’s hand, and the long, slow, patient endurance of its service. It had been part of a whole, and now it was a fragment, yet it had not forgotten its purpose. It was a single, coherent word in a sentence that had been erased.

With painstaking effort, he brought Barth to the spot, positioning him so that he was sitting on the grass beside the solitary stone. The catatonic sprite offered no resistance, his limbs moving with a pliant, unnerving obedience. Kaelan took Barth’s limp, three-fingered hand and placed it flat against the worn, smooth surface of the flagstone. The stone was cold, but it held a latent, phantom warmth from the morning sun. Kaelan then placed his own hand over Barth’s, creating a small, living seal on the ancient surface. He closed his eyes, not to summon power, but to open a channel. He focused on the slack tether that bound their souls, and gently, tentatively, he began to share. He did not send memories or concepts, but the raw, empathetic feeling he was drawing from the stone itself: a sense of deep time, of patient service, of being a fragment that still held the memory of the whole. He offered the stone’s quiet, uncomplaining endurance as a silent argument against the violent finality of despair.

For a long moment, the only response was the whisper of the wind through the shattered archway. The tether remained slack. Then, a shudder ran through Barth’s body, a violent, rattling tremor that shook him from head to toe. His vacant, mismatched eyes squeezed shut, a grimace of profound and terrible pain twisting his features. A sound tore from his throat, the first vocalization he had made since his collapse. It was not a word, but a low, guttural groan, a noise of pure, undiluted agony as if a limb, long dead, was suddenly having its circulation restored in a flood of searing pins and needles. A single tear escaped the corner of his tightly shut blue eye, tracing a clean path through the grime on his cheek. The pain was a sign of life, but it was a life of unbearable torment.

Kaelan felt the feedback through the tether as a physical blow. Barth’s agony, the agony of a soul beginning to feel its own shattered state for the first time, slammed into him, a wave of pure psychic noise. He was forced to break the connection, snatching his hand away as if the stone had turned red-hot. He fell back, gasping, his own spirit reeling from the shared trauma. The groan from Barth subsided, and his face returned to its slack, empty state, but the tear remained, a glistening testament to the brutal reality of the process. Kaelan understood with a terrifying clarity that this was not a gentle mending. The void he had found Barth in was not just an emptiness; it was a sanctuary, a self-imposed anesthesia against a pain too great to be borne. To heal him, he first had to force him to feel the full, unblinking horror of his own wound.

Each morning began with the same ritual: the gathering of dew, the foraging for berries or edible roots, and the slow, painstaking process of feeding the empty vessel that was Barth. Kaelan learned to read the subtle signs of the ruin as a text. The way the ivy grew thicker on the north-facing walls taught him about shelter from the wind. The presence of tiny, hardy ferns in a fissure spoke of a place where water seeped through the stone. He was no longer a being of grand concepts, but a creature of practicalities, his existence defined by the search for warmth, water, and a story hardy enough to survive the telling.

He did not attempt to connect with Barth every day. The backlash of shared agony was too great, leaving him dizzy and nauseous, his own spirit feeling frayed and thin. He had to let the psychic wounds scab over, to allow the violent echoes to fade before he could risk another session. In the intervening days, he simply cared for his charge. He would clean the grime from Barth’s face, re-bandage scratches with broad leaves, and talk to him. He spoke in a low, quiet murmur, not expecting a response, but simply to fill the vast silence between them. He described the flight of a jackdaw, the way the light caught a droplet of dew on a spider’s web, the patient work of a line of ants. He was weaving the world back into existence with simple, spoken words, hoping a single thread might catch in the empty loom of Barth’s mind.

He propped him against the base of the wall, then took his hand and placed it on the stone, near the lowest of the flowers. He laid his own hand over it, closed his eyes, and braced himself. He shared the feeling of intertwined roots, of a shared grip against the wind, of the collective turning of faces to the sun. He offered the quiet, communal joy of their existence, the way their combined fragrance created a presence far greater than any single blossom could achieve. He was weaving the concept of a clutch, of a community that finds its strength not in its uniformity, but in its shared hold within a flawed and broken world.

The reaction, when it came, was terrifyingly different. There was no groan of agony this time. Instead, a deep, shuddering sigh escaped Barth’s lips, a sound of profound and bottomless grief. The tether between them did not spike with pain, but flooded with a thick, murky wave of emotion, a confusing slurry of sorrow, nostalgia, and a ghostly, unfamiliar warmth. Through the connection, Kaelan received a fractured sensory impression: the smell of wet moss after a summer rain, the sound of many tiny voices chattering, the feeling of being pressed in on all sides not by a threat, but by a crowd. It was a memory fragment of the clutch, but stripped of the narrative of his failure, leaving only the raw, sensory truth of having once belonged. The memory was not a comfort; it was an amputation felt anew, a phantom limb aching with a life it could no longer lead.

Kaelan pulled back, his own eyes burning with unshed tears that were not entirely his. He had succeeded in waking something other than pure pain, but it was a grief so vast it threatened to drown them both. He had opened a door in the prison of Barth’s mind, only to reveal a room full of ghosts. He looked at Barth, whose face had once again fallen slack, but there was a new sadness in its lines, a subtle sculpting of loss that had not been there before. He had not just reminded Barth that he was broken; he had reminded him of what it felt like to be whole, and the contrast was a more refined and devastating form of torture. The work was so much more cruel than he had ever imagined.

The air over the Quay, even an hour before sunrise, tasted of salt and diesel fumes. A fine, gritty meal for a creature the size of a man’s thumb. Kaelan ignored it. He had learned long ago to filter the crass tang of the big folk’s world from the purer elements he worked with. Today, his material was the nascent light of dawn itself, a single, fraying strand of pearlescent gold that had snagged on the mast of a fishing trawler named ‘The Salty Dog’. If left untended, it would snap before the sun had properly breached the horizon, causing a momentary, imperceptible flicker in the morning’s arrival. Mortals wouldn’t notice. A few gulls might cry out in momentary confusion. But Kaelan would know. The world would be just that little bit less perfect, a single stitch dropped in the grand tapestry. And Kaelan did not abide dropped stitches.

He clung to a rust-pitted stanchion, his gossamer wings, patterned like a pebble from the shore, pressed tight to his back to avoid a snag. The wind was a bully this high up, a buffeting force that threatened to peel him from his perch and send him spiralling into the greasy, rainbow-sheened water below. It was delicate work. The sort of work that demanded absolute stillness, a quiet mind, and fingers that could coax a thread of mist without turning it to vapour. He held his breath. Slowly, Kaelan reached out, his tiny, three-fingered hands glowing with a soft internal luminescence. He wasn't grabbing the light. You couldn't grab light. You had to persuade it. He began to weave, not with a shuttle and loom, but with focused intent, his fingers dancing in the air, knotting the intangible. He was a Weaver, one of the last in the Poole Harbour clutch. His skill was not in making, but in mending. He could re-stitch a spider's web, bind the scent of gorse back into a bruised flower, or, on a very good day, persuade a fractured moonbeam to heal itself.

The golden thread responded to his touch, the frayed ends twisting, braiding, flowing back into a single, cohesive strand. He worked a Weaver’s Knot—a complex, seven-loop binding that was both stronger than the original thread and utterly invisible. A sigh of pure satisfaction escaped his lips, a tiny puff of air that was immediately snatched away by the wind. The strand of dawn was secure. The sun could now rise without blemish. His work here was done. He allowed himself a small, tight smile. It was a good mend. Clean. Precise. He was about to scuttle back down the stanchion, towards the relative safety of the pilings and crevices of the Quay, when he felt it.

It was a wrongness. A sour note in the symphony of the waking harbour. Not the familiar discord of humanity—the groan of engines, the distant shout of a deckhand—but something deeper. Something that felt like a plucked string inside his own chest. He cocked his head, his large, dark eyes scanning the panorama. The vast, dark water of the harbour stretched out towards Brownsea Island, a smudge of deeper black against the charcoal sky. The chain ferry was a slumbering metal beast on the Sandbanks side. Everything looked as it should. Yet, the feeling persisted. It was a subtle unraveling. He scrambled down the cold metal, his bare feet finding purchase on rivet heads and flakes of rust, until he reached the damp, creosote-soaked timbers of the pier. Here, in the under-world of the Quay, the sounds and smells were sharper, more immediate. The slap of water against wood, the scuttling of unseen crabs, the pervasive stink of brine and decay.

An elder sprite, Elara, was waiting for him, perched on a discarded oyster shell. Her wings, the colour of dried seaweed, were tattered at the edges, and her face was a roadmap of worry. She’d been a Weaver once, but her hands were now gnarled with age and the damp, better suited to prophesying aches in her joints than mending the world.
“You felt it too,” she stated. It wasn’t a question. Her voice was the rasp of beetle-chitin on dry leaves.

Kaelan nodded, hopping from a damp patch to a relatively dry spot of wood. “A discord. Over by the trawlers. I thought at first it was just a snapped dawn-thread, but the mend felt… slick.” He struggled for the right word. “Like I was stitching oil to water. It held, but it didn't *want* to.”

Elara’s dark eyes seemed to shrink, becoming hard little beads of jet. “It’s him. It’s his humour spreading again. Like a stain.”

Kaelan’s stomach tightened. He didn't need to ask who ‘he’ was. There was only one sprite in living memory who could cause such a feeling, a sprite whose very existence was an act of metaphysical vandalism. Bartholomew. Barth, to all who feared or loathed him, which was everyone.

“What did he do?” Kaelan asked, his voice low.

“You know what he does,” Elara rasped, shifting on her shell. “He tells jokes. He was seen over by the reed beds of the Hole’s Bay mudflats last night. Old Corvus the woodlouse said he heard him. A chuckle first, like stones rolling in a tin can. Then the words.” She shuddered, a tremor that shook her whole tiny frame. “He told a joke to a patch of sea-thrift. Asked it what the difference was between a flower and a puddle of sick.”

Kaelan felt a wave of nausea. “And?”

“And now there’s a patch of land by the water’s edge, about a stride across for a big folk, where nothing grows. It’s not just dead, Kaelan. It’s… resolved. The very soil has forgotten how to be soil. It’s just brown grit. The thrift didn’t just die, it… it believed the punchline.”

This was Barth’s particular brand of horror. His jokes weren’t just words. They were corrosive suggestions whispered to the fabric of reality. He didn’t use magic in the way Kaelan or the other sprites did. He didn’t weave or bind or persuade. He found a loose thread in the world’s logic and he pulled, not with force, but with a perfectly constructed, terribly inappropriate jest. He could tell a stone it was actually a bubble, and it would float away for a second before popping into dust. He could ask a cloud why it was in such a hurry and it would stop, forgetting its purpose, and simply hang in the sky until it curdled and fell as greasy, black rain. His humour was the auditory equivalent of rust, of rot, of entropy.

“He can’t be allowed to continue,” Kaelan said, the words feeling heavy and useless in his mouth. “The clutch-elders…”

“The elders are old,” Elara cut in, her voice sharp with a frustration that mirrored his own. “They hide. They wring their hands and talk of the old ways and how things are not as they once were. They hope he’ll get bored and wander off. But he’s not getting bored, Kaelan. He’s getting better. His jokes are becoming more… ambitious.”

As if to punctuate her words, a sudden, unnatural silence fell over their small section of the under-quay. The constant, rhythmic lapping of the water against the pilings ceased. Not faded, not quieted. It simply stopped. Kaelan and Elara froze, listening to the non-sound. It was more disturbing than any noise. The water was still there, he could see its dark, undulating surface. But it was making no noise. It had forgotten how.

Then they heard it. A faint, wheezing chuckle drifting from further down the pier. It was a wet, unpleasant sound, full of phlegm and malice.

“Why is the sea so quiet?” a voice whispered, seeming to come from all directions at once. It was a thin, reedy voice, but it carried a weight that made the timbers vibrate. Kaelan felt the hairs on his arms stand on end.

The voice paused, a perfect, theatrical beat.

“Because it saw the Quay and didn’t want to wake the sleepers!”

The punchline landed in the air like a dead weight. And then, a sound returned to the water. But it wasn’t the familiar, gentle lapping. It was a thick, syrupy slopping. A glutinous, sucking noise, like mud trying to swallow a boot. Kaelan peered over the edge of the beam. The water below had changed. It had thickened, its surface now disturbingly viscous, covered in a film like cooling gravy. A dead fish floated by, not on the water, but half-submerged in it, trapped in the gelid surface. The very nature of the water had been perverted by a single, stupid joke.

“No,” Kaelan breathed. He could feel the wrongness spreading, a stain of corrupted physics. This wasn’t a fray to be mended. This was a fundamental truth that had been lied to, and had believed the lie. He looked at Elara. The worry in her eyes had been replaced by stark terror.

“He’s close,” she whispered. “He’s never been this close to the heart of the clutch.”

Kaelan felt a surge of something cold and hard in his chest. It wasn't fear, not entirely. It was a cold, sharp anger. An artisan’s fury at the sight of a masterpiece being defaced. His world, with all its intricate, fragile beauty, was being turned into a grotesque caricature by a nihilistic jester. He looked down at his hands, the faint light still glowing around his fingertips. His skills were for mending, for healing, for reinforcing the fragile order of things. But what good was a needle against a flood? What good was a Weaver when the very threads were being taught to unravel themselves from within? He didn’t have an answer. But as the foul, slopping sound of the bewitched water echoed beneath him, he knew he had to find one. He had to stop Barth. Not because the elders decreed it, not for the glory of the clutch, but because the alternative was a world where the sea made the sound of mud and flowers turned to sick at the telling of a bad joke. And that was no world at all.

Kaelan moved towards the sound, a grim determination setting his tiny jaw. The slopping of the corrupted water was an offense to every one of his senses. He had to see. He had to understand the extent of the damage. Elara scrabbled after him, her tattered wings dragging on the damp wood. “Don’t go near him, Kaelan! There’s nothing you can do. You mend things that are broken, but this… this isn’t broken. It’s been… convinced. It’s worse.” Her voice was a high, desperate whine, lost under the thick, unsettling sound of the water. Kaelan didn’t reply. He couldn’t. The artisan in him was screaming louder than Elara’s fear. This was not a dropped stitch; this was someone taking a blowtorch to the tapestry.

He reached the edge of the pier and peered down the long, dark corridor of the under-quay. The air was thick with a new smell, mingling with the salt and creosote—an acrid, chemical odour like burnt sugar. Further down, silhouetted against a gap in the pilings that showed the faintly lightening sky, was a figure. It was another sprite, hunched over, his form distorted and twitching with silent laughter. Even from this distance, Kaelan could see the wrongness of him. His wings were not like a pebble or a leaf or a moth, but were a chaotic, mismatched pair. One looked like a shard of oily, rainbow-slicked glass, the other was a tattered piece of a lottery ticket, its numbers faded and meaningless. This had to be Barth.

Barth was talking to something, his reedy voice a low murmur that Kaelan couldn’t quite decipher. His audience was a cluster of barnacles, clinging to a great wooden piling. As Kaelan watched, his stomach churning, Barth leaned in close, as if sharing a secret, and delivered a final, whispered line. A moment of absolute stillness followed. Then, one by one, the barnacles began to squeak. It was a high, thin sound, like air escaping a pinpricked balloon. They detached from the wood, not falling, but drifting lazily upwards, spinning in the air like grey, calcified seeds. They floated up through the gaps in the pier decking and were gone, having been convinced they were bubbles. Barth let out another wet, wheezing chuckle of delight. He had taught a colony of sessile crustaceans a joke about gravity.

This was the antithesis of everything Kaelan was. A Weaver worked with the world as it was, honouring its rules, respecting its integrity. Barth saw the rules as a cosmic joke waiting for a punchline. He saw the integrity of a thing as a set-up, a straight man for his nihilistic wit. Anger, cold and pure, burned away the last of Kaelan’s fear. He wasn’t a warrior. He didn’t have a thorn-blade or a pincer-claw like the clutch’s foragers and guards. He had his hands, his intent, and a profound, unshakable belief in the way things were *meant* to be. Perhaps that was a weapon of its own. He dropped from the beam, landing silently on the cross-strut below, and began to move towards the jester, a tiny, determined point of light in the deepening corruption of the under-quay.

Elara watched him go, a tiny sound of despair caught in her throat. She pressed herself into the shadows, making herself small, a creature of the old ways hiding from a horror the old ways had never prepared them for. Kaelan, however, felt a strange sense of clarity as he moved. The world around him was subtly warped. A patch of sea-lettuce had curled in on itself, trying to remember the colour green. A length of discarded fishing line was attempting to tie itself into a hangman’s noose, having been told a bleak joke about futility. Each wrongness was a breadcrumb, a testament to Barth's passing, and each one fuelled Kaelan’s resolve. He was no longer just a mender. He was an antibody, drawn to a sickness that threatened the entire organism. He crept closer, his internal light dimmed to a faint ember, his feet making no sound on the slime-coated beams. He was ten feet away when Barth spoke again, his voice oozing with mock conviviality.

“Well, well, well,” Barth chirped, without turning around. “If it isn’t the Golden Boy of the Weavers. The little stitch-witch himself. Come to admire my work? Or perhaps you’ve got a needle and thread big enough to sew the sea back together?” He finally turned, and Kaelan got his first proper look at him. Barth was thin and wiry, his skin the colour of a day-old bruise. His eyes were mismatched too; one was a bright, feverish blue, the other a dull, bored brown. They darted and danced, never settling, alight with a manic, destructive glee. A twisted smile stretched his mouth, a rictus of mirth that held no warmth at all. “It’s a bit of a fixer-upper, I’ll grant you,” he gestured with a flourish at the glutinous water. “But I think it has a certain… honesty. Don’t you? The sea always secretly wanted to be sludge. I just gave it permission.”

Kaelan stood his ground on the beam, the foul smell of Barth’s work thick in his throat. He kept his own voice level, fighting to keep it from trembling. “This isn’t permission, Barth. It’s a violation. You’re poisoning the order of things for your own amusement.”

Barth threw his head back and laughed, that same wet, grating sound. “Order! Oh, you precious little fool. There is no order. It’s all just a poorly told story, and the storyteller is a drunk. I’m just pointing out the plot holes. What do you call a spider’s web that catches the dew?” he asked, his mad eyes fixing on Kaelan. Before Kaelan could even process the question, Barth snapped the punchline. “A net loss!” As he spoke, a nearby web, a perfect orb beaded with pristine droplets, sagged. The dewdrops, suddenly imbued with impossible weight, tore through the silk strands, and the whole delicate structure collapsed into a useless, sticky tangle. The spider, a garden-orb weaver Kaelan had seen every morning for a month, scurried into a crack, its world literally torn apart.

Kaelan flinched as if struck. The casual, instantaneous destruction was obscene. He raised his hands, the soft light in them flaring instinctively. He couldn’t fix the sea, not all at once, but maybe… maybe he could fight one lie with one truth. He focused on the ruined web, on the memory of its perfection, on the fundamental law of surface tension and the inherent strength of spider-silk. He began to weave, not touching the web, but persuading its memory. He was trying to remind it of its own nature, to stitch its truth back into place over the hole Barth’s joke had made. “The web is strong,” he whispered, his fingers tracing patterns in the air. “The dew is light. This is their nature.”

The tangled strands quivered. A few of them tightened, trying to reform their old connections. It was like trying to mend a cloth that was actively fighting back, a fabric that now believed its purpose was to be torn. Barth watched him, his smile widening with sadistic curiosity. “Oh, that’s adorable. You’re trying to tell it a better story? So earnest. So… dull.” He leaned forward, his reedy voice dropping to a conspiratorial whisper aimed at the struggling web. “But why bother holding on? Letting go is so much easier. What did the thread say to the spider? ‘I’m hanging on by you!’”

The effect was immediate. The faint flicker of order Kaelan had coaxed into the web died instantly. The strands went limp, not just broken but… resigned. The web gave up. It accepted its new state of uselessness. Kaelan felt the resistance in his weaving vanish, replaced by a dead, unresponsive void. A trickle of sweat ran down his temple. He had tried to out-weave a punchline, and had failed. It was like trying to patch a hole with water. Barth’s power didn't just break things; it convinced them that being broken was their true, and funnier, state.

The echo of his failure was a cold, dead space in the air. Kaelan felt it as a physical vacancy, a pocket of nothing where the intricate logic of the web had been. He lowered his hands, the light within them flickering uncertainly. It was one thing to mend a tear caused by a clumsy gull or a brute gust of wind; those were wounds inflicted from the outside. This was a sickness from within, a rot of the soul. The web hadn't just broken; it had surrendered its very identity.

Barth clapped his mismatched hands together, a slow, mocking applause that sounded like stones cracking. “Bravo, bravo! A valiant effort. You see, this is your problem, Weaver. You think the world is a beautiful, intricate thing that sometimes gets a little torn. But you’re wrong. The world is a cosmic pratfall, a long, drawn-out joke at its own expense. I’m not breaking it. I’m just delivering the punchlines it’s been waiting to hear.” He gestured around at the corrupted space beneath the pier. “You’re a janitor, sweeping up. I’m a philosopher, revealing the truth. And the truth,” he leaned in, his reedy voice dropping to a hiss, “is that it’s all meaningless. And that’s hilarious.”

Every word was a splinter under Kaelan’s skin. Meaningless? He thought of the perfect, seven-loop knot he had just tied in the strand of dawnlight. He thought of the intricate patterns on his own wings, the result of a million tiny choices made by chance and time. He thought of the complex symphony of the harbour—the tides, the cycles of rust and renewal, the dance of predator and prey. It wasn't meaningless. It was the most meaningful thing he knew. It was everything. And this… creature… was turning it all into a sneering, nihilistic gag. A different kind of fire lit in Kaelan’s chest, colder and harder than his earlier anger. It was the icy resolve of a craftsman whose life’s work has been declared a joke.

He looked at his hands again. They were made for mending, for persuading. But persuasion relied on a shared understanding, a common belief in the thing being mended. He could not persuade the sea that it was water, because Barth had already convinced it that it was sludge. He couldn’t persuade the web to be strong, because Barth had already proven that letting go was funnier. The logic was undeniable. He could not win by arguing with a punchline. He could not mend what no longer believed in being whole. The realisation was terrifying, but it was also freeing. If mending was impossible, then he had to do something else. He was a Weaver. And a weave wasn’t just for repair. A good weave, a tight weave, was also for reinforcement.

Barth seemed to sense the shift in Kaelan, the change from bewildered fury to a grim, focused stillness. The jester’s smile faltered for a fraction of a second, his darting eyes pausing on Kaelan’s luminous hands. He had expected despair, a retreat. This quiet defiance was new, and therefore irritating. “Well, this has been fun,” he said with a dismissive flick of his lottery-ticket wing. “But I’m tired of heckling the background characters. I think it’s time to talk to the star of the show.” He turned and scurried away down the pier, his form a twitching silhouette against the lightening sky. “There’s a piling down here, the oldest one. They say the whole Quay is built around it. The Sovereign Piling. Solid, dependable, the heart of the clutch. I’ve been working on a real knee-slapper for it. Something about termites and ambition.”

Kaelan’s blood ran cold. The Sovereign Piling was more than just wood. It was their history, their anchor. It was the first place the Poole Harbour clutch had found shelter, its ancient, sea-soaked timber holding the memories of a thousand generations. To corrupt it would be to poison the very heart of their world. He didn’t hesitate. Pushing off the beam, he unfurled his wings and launched himself into the foul-smelling air, a tiny, glowing missile of desperate purpose. He flew low and fast, weaving through the forest of supporting struts, the thick, slopping sound of the gelid water a constant, nauseating drumbeat below. The world around him was a gallery of Barth’s petty cruelties. A line of rust on a metal plate was weeping, literally dripping flakes onto the wood below after being told a joke about its own decay. A small puddle shimmered and trembled, trying to achieve escape velocity after being convinced it was a rocket.

He had to get there first. He pushed himself faster, his pebble-patterned wings beating a frantic rhythm. He couldn't fix what Barth broke. He knew that now. He couldn't un-tell the joke. But what if he could make the piling deaf to it? What if he could reinforce its reality so strongly, bind its own truth to it so tightly, that Barth's corrosive wit would find no purchase? It wasn't mending. It was shielding. It was an act of magical conservation. Instead of stitching a tear, he would weave a knot of pure, unassailable *being* into the piling’s very core. He would remind it of its strength, its age, its purpose, its deep, quiet dignity. He would weave a truth so profound and fundamental that no joke, no matter how clever or cruel, could unravel it. It was a Weaver’s skill used not as a needle, but as a shield. He didn’t know if it would work. He didn’t even know if it was possible. But as he flew through the corrupted morning, with the sound of a mad sprite’s chuckling echoing behind him, he knew he had to try.

Chapter 2

He flew like a glowing dart through the forest of pier legs. The world he passed was a fever dream of Barth’s making. A small colony of mussels, renowned for their stoicism, were chattering nervously to each other, convinced by a rumour that the tide was never coming back in. A stray piece of driftwood, told it was a snake, was trying to writhe its way across the sludge-water, its movements stiff and unconvincing. Kaelan forced himself not to look, not to feel the pang of each individual corruption. To do so would be to dilute his focus, to scatter his intent. All that mattered was the Sovereign Piling. He could feel its presence now, not as a wrongness, but as a deep, resonant rightness in the chaotic symphony. It was a bass note, a foundation, and Barth was marching towards it with a metaphysical sledgehammer.

He arrived moments before his rival. The Sovereign Piling was immense, a pillar of ancient oak that was thicker than three men standing shoulder-to-shoulder. Its surface was a testament to time, scarred with the ghosts of long-rusted-away iron bands, pitted by shipworms, and softened by a coat of algae and velvet-fine sea moss. It plunged deep into the harbour bed and soared up into the main structure of the Quay, a central column around which everything else had been built. It smelled of deep, cold brine, of wet earth from its long-forgotten life as a tree, and something more: a profound, unshakable scent of permanence. Generations of the clutch had been born in its crevices, had sheltered from winter gales in its lee, and had watched the sun rise over its steadfast form. It was not a piling; it was their home.

Without a second’s hesitation, Kaelan landed on a projecting knob of wood and pressed both his hands against the piling’s flank. The wood was cold and damp, but beneath the surface, he could feel it—a slow, deep, geologic thrum. The piling’s memory. He closed his eyes and let his own light flow from his fingertips, not over the surface, but *into* it. This was no surface mend. He was not stitching frayed edges. He was delving into the very heartwood of the thing, seeking the core of its identity. He found the threads of its being: the concentric rings of its growth, the memory of sunlight on its leaves, the stoic endurance of a thousand winter storms, the faint, layered echoes of a million tiny sprite hands that had clung to it for safety. His own hands began to move, his fingers dancing against the wood. He was weaving those threads of truth together. He was not telling the piling what it was; he was reminding it, with all the force of his own belief in order and purpose. "Root," he thought, weaving the memory of its grip in the earth. "Heartwood," he projected, binding the concept of its strong, dense core. "Endurance. Shelter. Foundation. Home." Each concept was a knot, a reinforcement in the fabric of its reality.

A familiar, grating chuckle echoed from behind him. "Oh, this is rich," Barth sneered, sauntering into view from around a neighbouring strut. He stopped a few feet away, his mismatched eyes taking in the scene with theatrical amusement. "Look at you. Hugging the furniture. Are you trying to teach it a new trick? Or just polish it with your own self-importance?" He gestured with a lazy flick of his glass-shard wing. "You can't make it any more of a piling than it already is, you little pedant."

Kaelan did not answer. He couldn’t. His entire being was focused on the weave. The piling was responding. He could feel its immense, slow consciousness stirring, acknowledging the truths he was reinforcing. The faint light from his hands brightened, the patterns of his weaving becoming visible as shimmering lines of force that sank into the ancient oak, bathing the base of the pillar in a soft, protective luminescence. The scent of permanence, of deep, unassailable reality, grew stronger, pushing back against the acrid smell of burnt sugar and decay that clung to Barth like a shroud. This was his shield, a defence made of pure, concentrated is-ness.

Barth’s mocking smile tightened. He had clearly expected Kaelan to argue, to flail uselessly. This silent, focused opposition was infuriating. The light from Kaelan's work seemed to genuinely annoy him, a pure note in his carefully orchestrated symphony of discord. He took a step closer, his reedy voice taking on the cadence of a performer about to deliver his masterpiece. "You're too late, stitch-witch," he hissed. "I've had this one planned for weeks. It's my magnum opus. The joke that will bring the house down. Literally." He cleared his throat, a wet, rattling sound, and addressed the Sovereign Piling directly, his voice dripping with false intimacy.

"Alright, you big, strong, silent type. You've stood here a long time, holding everything up. Never a complaint. Terribly noble. Terribly boring." Barth’s grin widened into a predatory slit. "Let me ask you a question." He paused, letting the silence stretch, a showman milking the moment. Kaelan felt a tremor of pure malice in the air, a vibration that threatened to shake his delicate weave apart. He pressed harder, pouring every ounce of his will, his belief, his love for the world's perfect, ordered logic into the piling. The light around its base flared into a brilliant, defiant shield.

Barth ignored it. His mad blue eye fixed on the heart of the ancient wood. "What," he asked, his voice suddenly sharp and clear, "did the ambitious termite say to the Sovereign Piling?"

The words hung in the air, a perfectly constructed vector of conceptual poison. Kaelan felt the psychic impact of them hit his weave like a physical blow. The light from his hands wavered, the intricate patterns of truth he had woven into the piling flickering like a faulty glow-worm. The joke wasn't just words; it was a syllogism of decay, a perfectly logical, terribly corrosive suggestion aimed at the very heart of the piling’s purpose.

“‘It’s nothing personal,’ he wheezed, his voice bubbling with glee, ‘I’m just here to undermine your authority!’”

The punchline landed. And the Sovereign Piling, for the first time in its centuries of existence, shuddered. It was not the tremor of a physical strain, but a deep, internal groan of conceptual conflict. A fine, dry powder of ancient wood began to sift down from deep within its core, a substance that wasn't sawdust but pure, desiccated doubt. The piling had understood the joke. It had processed the logic: it was a sovereign, an authority. To undermine was the natural ambition of a lesser power. The joke was, in its own terrible way, perfectly reasonable. Kaelan felt the threads of his weave—the concepts of ‘Foundation’ and ‘Strength’—begin to slacken, losing their tautness as the piling began to question its own role.

Barth howled with laughter, a triumphant, rattling crow of a sound that echoed through the under-quay. "Do you feel it, stitch-witch? Do you feel the beautiful, simple logic of it? It's giving up! It understands the gag! It's so much easier to be rubble than to hold up a world, isn't it?" The sifting dust became thicker. The deep, resonant thrum of the piling's being grew discordant, a beautiful bass note now soured by a new, grating frequency of self-destruction. Kaelan’s shield of pure being was failing, because the being itself no longer fully believed in its own purpose.

Desperation clawed at him. He couldn’t reinforce a truth that was actively being unpicked from the inside. He was trying to shout "You are strong!" at a being that was now contemplating the philosophical elegance of being weak. It was a losing argument. His entire approach was wrong. Weaving logic against a paradox was like trying to dam a river with a net. And then, as the great pillar groaned again, a sound of immense, slow-motion sorrow, a new thought sparked in Kaelan’s mind. Barth's power came from twisting the logic of a thing, its function, its name. He had attacked the *Sovereign Piling*. But that wasn't all it was. That was just its title. What was its *truth*?

He changed his weave. The shift was instinctive, desperate, and utterly profound. He stopped weaving the cold, hard facts of the piling's existence—its strength, its age, its function. Instead, he reached for something deeper, something Barth’s cynical wit could never touch. He reached for its soul. His fingers, still pressed against the wood, moved in a new, frantic, yet graceful dance. He stopped weaving concepts and started weaving memories. He poured the collective memory of the clutch into the wood, a thousand years of lived experience. He wove the feeling of a young sprite’s hand finding a secure grip during a storm. He wove the memory of two elders sharing a berry in its shadow. He wove the scent of his own mother’s wings as she sheltered him in a crevice of its bark. He wove the sound of laughter, of grief, of birth-songs and death-chants, all of which the piling had absorbed in its silent vigil. He stopped trying to convince it that it was a *foundation* and started reminding it, with all the power of his being, that it was a *home*.

Barth’s laughter faltered. He cocked his head, his mismatched eyes narrowing in confusion. The quality of the light emanating from Kaelan’s hands had changed. The brilliant, cold-white shield of pure logic was softening, warming into a deep, golden glow, like honey or amber. It pulsed with a gentle, rhythmic beat, like a slow, content heart. The groaning of the piling lessened, its discordant note fading. "What are you doing?" Barth hissed, the humour draining from his voice to be replaced by a raw, naked irritation. "That's not weaving. That's… sentiment." The word was an insult, the foulest curse he could imagine.

Kaelan didn't hear him. He was lost in the weave, binding the piling not with what it *was*, but with *who* it was for. He found the central thread of the piling's being and tied to it a new knot, a knot that Barth’s logic couldn't unpick because it wasn't made of logic. It was a knot of love. He wove until his entire being ached with the effort, until the golden light was a blinding sun in the darkness of the under-quay. The sifting of dust stopped. The great, ancient pillar settled, a profound stillness falling over it. It had not defeated the joke. It had not even rejected it. It had simply found a deeper, more compelling reason to exist, a reason that rendered the clever, nihilistic joke completely and utterly irrelevant. A termite’s ambition meant nothing to a home.

The Sovereign Piling stood, its reality now anchored not in its physical strength, but in its place at the heart of a community. Barth stared, his jaw slack, his mismatched eyes wide with a dawning, horrified comprehension. His joke hadn't been disproven; it had been ignored. His sharpest, most carefully crafted piece of metaphysical vandalism had been rendered meaningless by a wave of messy, illogical emotion. It was the ultimate artistic failure. He looked from the glowing, peaceful piling to the small, exhausted sprite clinging to its side, and his face contorted in a mask of pure, undiluted rage.

"That's cheating," he spat, the words small and venomous. His laughter was gone. The gleeful showman had vanished, leaving only a bitter, withered creature whose greatest trick had failed. There was no wit left in him, only spite. With a final, hateful glare, he turned and scurried away into the shadows, a chaotic smear of wrongness retreating from the warm, golden glow of Kaelan’s work. He did not chuckle. He did not deliver a parting shot. For the first time, Barth, the jester of entropy, had nothing funny to say. Kaelan slumped against the piling, his strength utterly spent, the light in his hands fading to a soft ember. The air around him was clean again, tasting only of salt and old wood. He had won. He hadn't just mended a thing; he had defended its very soul.

Chapter 3

The golden light receded, folding back into Kaelan’s fingertips until only a faint, weary pulse remained. He slid down the rough bark of the Sovereign Piling, his legs buckling as his feet touched the damp crossbeam below. The exertion had hollowed him out, leaving a ringing silence in its wake where moments before there had been a roaring torrent of will and memory. He leaned his head back against the ancient wood, feeling its deep, slow thrum. It was no longer discordant. The sour note was gone, replaced by a calm, steady resonance, the quiet hum of a thing that knows its purpose not as a definition, but as a deep and abiding feeling. It felt like home.

A new sound reached his ears, faint at first, then growing in confidence. It was the gentle, rhythmic lapping of water against wood. Kaelan pushed himself upright and peered over the edge of the beam. The horrid, viscous sludge was thinning, its gelatinous skin breaking apart. The unnatural silence was gone, replaced by the familiar music of the harbour. The water was not yet clear—it was still murky, tinged with the memory of its perversion—but it was liquid again. It was remembering how to be water. The dead fish, released from its gelatinous prison, bobbed and began to drift away on the nascent current. It seemed the Sovereign Piling’s restored reality was radiating outwards, a quiet but insistent truth that was slowly overwriting Barth’s spiteful lies. The weeping rust ceased its tears, the chattering mussels fell silent, and the piece of driftwood gave up its ambition to be a snake, settling into a placid, inanimate bob. The under-quay was healing itself.

Slowly, shakily, Kaelan began to make his way back. Each step was an effort, his wings feeling as heavy as lead plates. He passed the collapsed spider web, but did not stop. He knew, with a weary certainty, that it would not be mended. Its tiny spark of being had been extinguished, not just broken. His new method was a shield, not a resurrection. He could defend, but he could not yet raise the dead. The thought settled in his chest, a small, hard stone of sorrow amidst the relief. He had won, but there were still casualties.

He found Elara where he had left her, a tiny, seaweed-coloured shape huddled in the lee of a rusted bollard. She stared at him, her beetle-black eyes wide with an emotion he couldn't immediately place. It wasn't just relief; it was awe. As he drew closer, she scuttled forward, her gnarled hands reaching out but not quite touching him, as if he were made of spun glass.
"It's gone," she rasped, her voice trembling. "The wrongness. The… the sour taste in the world. It’s gone. How?"

"I… I don't know," Kaelan admitted, his voice barely a whisper. "I couldn't fix it. I couldn't fight his logic. So I used something else." He looked at his hands, still faintly luminous. "I used us. Our memories. I reminded the Piling it was our home."

Elara stared at him, and a slow, deep understanding dawned in her ancient eyes. She had been a Weaver. She understood the language of threads and knots, of concepts and truths. What he described was a weave she had never imagined, a knot tied with an intangible, emotional thread. Before she could speak again, they were interrupted. Other sprites were emerging, drawn from their hiding places by the cessation of the metaphysical noise. They crept out from behind loose planks, from within empty crab shells, and down from the shadowy rafters. They were the nail-biters, the hand-wringers, the ones who had hidden from Barth’s terror. Now, they stared at Kaelan, their faces a mixture of fear, bewilderment, and dawning hope. The story was passing between them in hushed, urgent whispers, a current of information as real as the returning tide. *Kaelan faced him. He drove him off. The Piling is whole.*

The awe was short-lived, replaced by the rigid hand of tradition. A stern-faced sprite with wings like chips of flint dropped from an overhead beam, landing with a sharp tap of his feet. It was Lorcan, the Warden of the Clutch-Elders. "Kaelan. You are summoned," he stated, his voice devoid of warmth or congratulation. "The Elders will see you. Now." The small crowd of sprites parted nervously, their hopeful expressions dimming under the weight of officialdom. Kaelan felt a cold knot form in his stomach, a stark contrast to the warm, golden one he had woven into the Piling. He had expected gratitude, perhaps even celebration. He had not expected a summons that felt more like an accusation.

He followed Lorcan in silence, with Elara trailing a few paces behind, her worry having returned tenfold. They did not go to the great hollow within the Sovereign Piling, but to a dry, dusty chamber high up in the pier’s superstructure, a place of governance and judgment. Three elders were waiting, perched on a tribunal of weathered sea-smoothed stones. Their wings, like brittle autumn leaves, were folded tight. Their faces were grim. The chief elder, a sprite named Cormac whose skin was as wrinkled and grey as dried mud, fixed his gaze on Kaelan.
"You confronted Bartholomew," Cormac said, his voice the dry rustle of sand. It was not a question.

"He was corrupting the Sovereign Piling. He would have brought the Quay down," Kaelan replied, his own voice sounding thin and young in the oppressive silence of the chamber. "I stopped him."

"You did not 'stop' him in the manner of our ways," the second elder, a female named Briony, interjected. Her voice was sharp, like the crack of a dried seed pod. "You did not reinforce. You did not mend. The Warden’s report says you used… sentiment. You wove memories and feelings into the Piling. Is this true?"

The cold knot in Kaelan’s stomach tightened. "His joke was based on logic. My logic couldn't beat his. I had to use a truth he couldn't twist. The truth of what the Piling means to us."

Cormac leaned forward, his dark eyes like holes in his dusty face. "You fool," he breathed, and the words struck Kaelan with more force than Barth’s most potent jest. "You reckless, arrogant child. The Tapestry of the world is woven with the threads of law. Physics, causality, nature, logic. They are strong, predictable, eternal. You have taken the most volatile, the most ephemeral of things—emotion, feeling, *love*—and you have woven it into a foundation. You have patched a hole in a stone wall with smoke."

"But it worked!" Kaelan protested, a flare of anger cutting through his exhaustion. "The smoke held! His poison couldn't touch it!"

He tried to summon his power, to focus his hate on a nearby railing and watch it crumble, but the effort was immediately short-circuited by a ghostly memory of sharing a particularly sweet drop of nectar with another sprite. The contradiction was agonizing, a logical paradox warring within his very soul. With a choked, desperate sound that was half-sob and half-snarl, he turned and fled, scrambling over the jetties and vanishing into the shadows of the quay, driven not by purpose, but by a panicked, desperate need to outrun the echoes of happiness now polluting his own heart.
